item.title: Privacy Policy
Constraints on variable t-flapping in Northern English give insight into the progression, and reduction, of phonological processes
Getextipa[R]ing betextipa[R]er all the time? The decline of t-flapping in Lancashire.
Knowing your /r/s from your elbow: looking at variation and change in English rhoticity
Locating speakers in the socioeconomic hierarchy: towards the optimal indicators of social class
Monophthongisation of `like' in two British capitals: effects of function, context and frequency
t-flapping vs. glottalling in Lancashire, London and beyond: a sociophonological analysis of variation and change
Categorical or gradient? An ultrasound investigation of /l/-darkening and vocalization in varieties of English
item.description:
Click the Cite button above to demo the feature to enable visitors to import publication metadata into their reference management software.
Click the Slides button above to demo Academic’s Markdown slides feature.

Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.

item.title: Not quite the same: The social stratification of the textscfoot-strut vowels in Manchester.
The textscFoot-Strut vowels in Manchester: Evidence for the diachronic precursor to the split?
The textscFoot-Strut vowels in Manchester: synchronic evidence for the historical trajectory of the split?
t-flapping in present day Northern English: implications for sociophonological change
A stationary frequency effect in Manchester English
Ahead but not faster: The effect of high token frequency on sound change
The morphological effect in British English T/D-deletion
Unstressed vowel backing in Manchester English
4,000 /r/s from Blackburn, Lancashire: A (socio)phonological analysis of rhoticity in Northern England
A constant rate effect in Manchester /t/-glottalling: high-frequency words are ahead of, but change at the same rate as, low-frequency words
Absence of a blocking r[textipaYl]?: the presence of /u/-fronting before /l/ in Manchester
Determining categoricity in English /l/-darkening: a principal component analysis of ultrasound spline data
T/D-deletion in British English revisited: Evidence for the long-lost morphological effect
The interaction of /u/-fronting and /l/-darkening in Manchester
/l/-darkening in varieties of English: A dialectological approach to articulatory variation.
/u/-fronting before /l/ in Manchester: Linguistic or social parallelism?
An ultrasound investigation of Northern English /l/s
Categorical and gradient patterns of lenition in ultrasound data
Crowdsourcing dialectology in the undergraduate classroom
Monophthongisation of 'like' in two British capitals: effects of function, context and frequency
Our Dialects
Quantifying tongue shapes during speech: A Principle Components Analysis of ultrasound /l/-darkening data.
Sociophonetic variation of 'like' in British dialects
Ultrasound evidence for gradient and categorical components of English /l/ lenition processes
inguistic and social constraints on consonantal variation in Manchester English.
t[textipa0:l] c[textipa0:] for sch[textipa0:l]: the interaction of /u/-fronting and /l/-darkening in Manchester
An ultrasound investigation of /l/-darkening in varieties of English
An ultrasound study of contextual patterns of /l/-darkening in varieties of British English
Categorical or gradient? Investigating patterns of /l/-darkening and vocalisation in varieties of English.
Categoricity, gradience and morphosyntactic domains in /l/-darkening
Crossing the Pond: Extending Automatic Alignment Techniques to British English Dialect Data
Crossing the Pond: Extending Automatic Alignment Techniques to British English Dialect Data
/textipaI, @/-lowering in Manchester: Contextual patterns of gradient variability.
Happ[textipaI] Talk: a socio-phonological analysis of unstressed vowels in Mancunian English
Higher or lower? Unstressed vowel variation in Mancunian English.
The morphosyntactic conditioning of /l/ in English: Synchronic reflections of the life cycle of phonological processes
Unstressed vowel lowering in Mancunian English: a socio-phonological study
Accounting for morphosyntactically conditioned phonological variation
The darkening of English /l/: a Stochastic Stratal OT Analysis
The FOOT-STRUT vowels in Manchester. Evidence for the diachronic precursor to the split?
